column11: Review Text

column8: Exploring Bambarakanda & Hidden Lanka Ella Falls
column11: We took a bus which was going towards colombo, and got down at bambarkanda waterfall. For the last mile we took auto. Bambarkanda waterfall has well marked route, and there is another fall behind- Lanka Ella waterfall. Lanka ella fall is not well marked though. We tried going up but couldnt trace the path as we started late in evening. Its better to start early for this fall so that you get good amount of time to relax and swim too.
This was a very nice waterfall! The walk is roughly 400m although there is lots of incline! The waterfall was very nice!!

Hidden Gem Located near the viewing point of Bambarakanda waterfalls this tiny oneâ€‘man quaint roadside coffee stand is nothing short of a revelation.. What makes this place extraordinary isnâ€™t just its astonishingly good coffeeâ€”itâ€™s the care and attention lavished on every cup by the very polite owner cum barista . This unassuming outpost proves that great coffeeâ€”and even greater kindnessâ€”can thrive in the most unexpected places. This great coffee experience far exceeds anything youâ€™d expect in such a remote spot.

column8: Amazing Experience at Tallest waterfall of Sri Lanka
column11: nice place ,can comfortably  go near to the fall by any vehicle  .then only less than  500metres walk and hike. But no place to rest except one private tea center .it is also not opened everyday. Bathing is not recommended as sudden rise of water beam can happened.

The  Turn off is on the Belihul Oya- Haputale  Road. Can be hiked - uphill all the way. I took a Tuk Tuk costing Rs 4,500 (about USD 15) to the ticket office. The pathway thru the bush was well maintained - takes about  15 minutes write up to the base of the Falls.  If in the area well worth a visit to Sri Lankaâ€™s highest Waterfall

263 meters high, it is the highest waterfall in the country. Entrance costs 350 rupees and allows you to access the waterfall after a walk of about 500 metres. Inside there is also another 2 km path to reach another small waterfall. To reach the entrance I recommend leaving the car at the beginning of the steep climb and using a tuk tuk (for 2000 rupees it will take you to the top, wait for you and take you back to the starting point)

column8: The tallest waterfall in sri lanka
column11: Babarakanda falls is situated in Kalupahana. The Babarakanda falls can be found in a forest of pine trees. It is beautiful falls. Traveling to this place is not easy as to the other falls of Sri Lanka.
Situated in Kalupahana in the Badulla District,The bambarakanda fall can be found in a forest of pine trees.Tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka and very beautiful place...
we went there to see .there was a lot of walking. almost half an hour to an hour.but the walking was worth it.the falls were awesome

Tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka and very beautiful place. And that place have grate view of waterfall and also there is a bathing place under ther fall. And also beautiful pinas jungle around the path to waterfall.
This is located between Belihuloya and Haputhale. Need to take a detour from main road in a narrow road and if you wish to go closer to the fall need to walk too....

Yes, this is the tallest waterfall. The access road is 5 km away from the Colombo - Badulla main road. If you are traveling from Colombo, turn left at Kalupahana small town. There's a huge sign board at the junction. This road is heading to Ohiya. Very small road, not well maintained. Careful driving is recommended. After about 5 km, you can find the access to this waterfall. There's an office maintained by a local government authority. Need to buy tickets. Parking space available. The footpath is well maintained. Beware of leaches. Best advice is wear shoes and do not wait more than one minute at a single place. Keep moving is good. Washroom facilities available. The view point is very safe. Do not walk out of the footpath because this area is very steep and be dangerous. No bathing is allowed. The environment is very nice. Good for nature photographers as well.

The water fall is 790 Ft in hight is the highest in sri lanka.You have to drive about 6 kms on a narrow bendy road to reach the fall.Once the motorble road is over you have to walk about 600 m to reach the bottom of he fall,wher lot of leaches are ther to climb your foot.

Bambarakanda waterfall, is the Highest waterfall in Sri-Lanka.  It is ranked as the 299th Highest Fall in the world. Saw it from a distance, but it was  a very beautiful sight, as it was after the rains. So the water was gushing and it was an amazing view. A very refreshing sight even from a distance.

I and my wife had visit this beautiful masterpiece last year and it was an amazing experience for both of us. A beautiful cascading waterfall and the highest in Sri Lanka. We came at the bottom of the waterfall through a pines forest. It was the most beautiful waterfall I have ever seen in Sri Lanka and a natural pool was there at the bottom of the falls. Can't imagine how much time I have stayed there in this calm environment. Highly recommend this place for all nature-lovers and you will not waste this opportunity as there were three or more waterfalls at the neighborhood. Please do not bring any non degradable items as all of us have to preserve this place...

The waterfall is very beautiful . Surrounding area is also beautiful . Recommend to go early in the day as it tends to get crowded in the afternoon and specially during weekends where people come in groups.It is a safe place to have a bath.

The waterfalls is a pretty slight. The walk up to that is beautiful. Recommend to go early in the day as it tends to get crowded in the afternoon and specially during weekends where people come in groups.
That picture i got to up hill of Bambarakanda.that 8s a nice chilling waterfall of the sri lanka with uniq expirience.

Itâ€™s my first time in sri lanka and my boyfriend bring me and the family to the tallest falls in sri lanka. It was so beautiful you can see the beauty of nature. It was well preserve, just to tell you they have ticket to go inside and the tourists have little bit expensive entrance fee than the locals. But all worth it. Hope to come again We enjoy so much

If you are in the Haputhale area then this is a must visit. located on the Devil's stair case route Kalupahana-Ohiya (Towards kalupahana) this is the perfect place for a dip after a tiring hike on the mountains. there are many Hiking trails in the area such as Wangedigala, Devils's stair case and all of these trails are crossing Bambarakanda waterfall. it's a short walk from the road through the jungle and pine trees before you arrive at this beauty and on a Sunny day this is the perfect shower coming from the hills. it can be crowded on weekends , so if you are visiting this place on a weekend in a Holiday be sure to go early morning.
A good place to have a small tracking in the waterfall area also will be a good looking fall with a dynamic view very happy will be

We visited the Bambarakanda Falls, which is the highest waterfall (almost 800m). The access road was narrow but cars and vans can easily access it. The site has been developed recently with guard rails, steps and toilets. There was less water when we visited but this is a worthwhile stop if you are into waterfalls.

This is the highest waterfall in Sri Lanka. Access road is narrow and small vehicles like cars and vans would be the suitable option to reach here. A small area is available for parking. Entry ticket is 20 rupees. Thereâ€™s a pathway that leads to the bottom of the falls. Itâ€™s basically dry most of the year. But can be very violent in the rainy season.

I went there with my family on last year. It is situated in Klaupahana, Sri Lanka. Having learnt & heard, Bambarakanda falls is the highest waterfall, we were curious to visit it. From the main road,Badulla-Colombo(99), There is a road about 5 kms,that leads to Bambarakanda Falls. You can go by a tuk tuk,by your own vehicle or you can walk. no any problems. Because you can have a original feeling of visiting a calm,cool & beautiful place. It was like searching a treasure. ðŸ¤­ðŸ™Š Finally, after about 5 kms, on the road, we found the entrance to the falls. then we have to buy tickets. And then, we can have & really enjoy a nice walk to the falls. Because, we have to walk through a forest, Through trees, on stairs,while listening to the voice of mother nature, It is really enjoyable. Finally, we can see the waterfall. We've never seen such a beautiful fall. Really,it makes us stay there. Calms our minds. So, the visit to bambarakanda falls is the most unforgettable journey in my life.
That is a tallest watefall in sri lanka with beautiful views of the edge of haputale city near by kalupahana area.

Bambarakanda Falls is located about 185 km away from Colombo in Kalupahana,  Haputale in Uva Province. It is about 795 feet above see level. This is supposed to be the tallest water fall in Sri Lanka. You have to get down from the vehicle and walk about 1/2km in to the jungle to reach the best place. Although the walking path is narrow it is not difficult to walk down.  The water falls down making a pond,  an excellent place for you to have a bath. Water is really fresh and cold. I think this is a place you must visit.

Bambarakanda is the tallest fall in Sri Lanka located in Uva Province. In your upcountry rail journey this is best location to visit. You can get down at Haputale Railway Station and reach this falls by bus or else you can get down at Ohiyo Railwaya Station and reach this falls via devil's stair case (a wonderful route in usually travelers used to reach this falls) 'Lanka Ella falls' do not forget to visit this hidden waterfall near Bamabrakanda falls. You can take the trail near bottom of the bamabrakanda to reach this hidden fall. A cool and beautiful place to visit. If can try to go to top of this falls which gives a best panoramic view with a wooden bridge. ~ Please leave only the footprints ~

Located bit off from the Colombo-Badulla main road. The turning point is in Kalupahana and pretty easy to miss. The waterfall premise is well maintained and requires some walking and climbing through a pines forest. Concrete steps are laid out for the ease of visitors.there is a podium on which visitors can admire the beauty of the falls safely. The base pool is not deep but there is a sign that says it is prohibited. Climbing up the waterfall is prohibited. There have been deaths by falling down. The water level is optimum from April to September.
You really feels like in heaven when you're close to the water fall which will sprincle you with tiny droplets and shroud you in the mist.

With a sheer drop of a 263 meters Bambarakanda Falls is the highest waterfall in SL and 299th highest in the world. Not visible from the main road. We travelled from Haputale towards Ratnapura to Kalupahana town and turn off at the sign board to Ohiya road. Then drove about 4 km along tarred narrow road to the parking spot. Had to pay a very low entrance free but it's worth way more than that. Walked about 500 m towards base of the falls. Steps along the way hasn't taken the natural beauty but made it easy for every one. Previous day rain gave us a best flow of water and much needed water spray. Can spend hours and hours sitting on a bench on the platform. What a beauty !! March to May months are the best for viewing. Proper walking shoes and early morning start would be ideal.
We went all the way to the top and it was amazing! But should pay attention to safety. View from the top is perfect!
Bambarakanda Falls is the tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka. Situated in Kalupahana in the Badulla District. You will love it when there so much water. If not it will look a bit dry.

Always worth visiting big waterfalls and this one did not disappoint, easy access via road.  And good view points, patrolled by police with some local stalls.  Very nice with easy roadside parking so no costs at all.

I caught the bus from Haputale to Kalupahana (8kms) and hiked 4 kms up the road to the entrance to the falls. Mostly the road went through the forest so i was in the shade. Just before the ticket office there were two small cafes where you could buy refreshments. As usual the locals got in free, but foreigners had to pay a minimal amount. From the ticket office a path led me through the forest and up a steep hill to the falls. Here i could sit on one of the benches and enjoy the view. Some locals were bathing in the pool at the bottom of the falls but it must have been cold. The falls are 240 m high and well worth visiting. I hiked back to the main road and caught the bus back to town.

Bambarakanda Falls is the tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka at 263 metres in height. The road to the waterfall is narrow and not suitable for large vehicles. The turnoff from Route A4 (Colombo - Batticaloa Highway) is at the Kalupahana Junction. You can walk to the waterfall but beware of bloodsucking leeches!

Whether you like trekking or simply want to tick off seeing Sri Lanka's highest waterfall, a visit is recommended. There is now a ticket counter and a fairly easy path from it to a point where the falls cascade into a pool where you can take photographs or take a dip.

The walk from the ticket counter to the waterfall is quite nice with glimpses of the waterfall on the way. An observation deck has been built now, and is easier for viewing and photography. The water is super cold and lovely.

It's wonderful place you should visit when travel haputhale, Bandarawela. You can  take a bath at that place and the view of the waterfall is marvellous. Being a tallest waterfall in sri Lanka this waterfall should  be your first choice when travel up country. It is located between bergala and belihuloya and 3 Km away from main road. You can use your own vehicle to travel and parking is available. From that point another 400 m should travel by barefoot to reach the destination.

I was there with my friends on 31st December 2017. highly recommend to take the train from colombo and enjoy the scenic train ride to ohiya. then follow the devils staircase all the way down only if u interested in hiking. if not you can catch the train from ohiya to haputhale and then catch a punagala- colombo bus to kalupahana junction. will charge 50 rupees if u go by a semi luxury bus (13Km).  then you can hire a tuk tuk from kalupahana junction to bambarakanda falls. they will charge 350 rupees from kalupahana junction to babarakanda entrance. You have to buy an entrance ticket ( 30 rupees ) then following an easy climb about 5 min you will reach to the fall. also there are 4 more water falls around there if u got more time.
you will need to walk 3km more after the google map says it is ending.  The view is amazing and love the local people there.  They are super friendly.

Bambarakanda waterfall is the highest in Sri Lanka. Situated in Badulla district. Can access from Colombo-Badulla highway near kalupahana junction by a vehicle. No need of off-road vehicle. If you are into hiking can be accsssed from ohiya via devils stair case. Highly recommend to take the train from Colombo and enjoy the scenic train ride to ohiya. Then follow the devils staircase all the way down. Not crowded trail so pretty much you are on your own. At the end of the trail can have a nice bath near the waterfall. Be aware of the sudden chang s in the water level..

Bambarakanda is significant being the highest waterfall in Sri Lanka, even-though most part of the year its limited to a thin veil of water. We reached the top of the falls after a long walk from Ohiya. The view from the top of the falls is quite fascinating. A trail through the pines forest leads to the bottom of the falls where one can enjoy a swim.
Its a long trek or a drive from the main road. Check on the water level before you start off as there's only a trickle of water in the dry season.
highest water fall in sri lanka  have to walk few steps to reach the bambarakanda falls  have to buy a ticket  from the main road to few km's which is not very good
Need to take the road to left from the Kalupahana junction in Belihuloya. When the time of visiting, there was not much of a water flow.

You can reach bambarakanda fall from 20 min drive after turning at Kalupahana junction in colombo- Batticaloa highway. You have to buy an entrance ticket ( small amount ). Then following an easy climb about 5 min you will reach to the fall. Ask details from the person at ticket counter. They will show you a safe place to bath, if it's a safe season to bath. Go there with extra time to spend, as you can ask a person from ticket counter to guide you to climb other water falls around. A must see waterfall is "Lanka Falls" , which has water collected pond shaped to Sri Lanka map. There are about 4 more water falls to see. It will take minimum 90 minutes to 4 hours to see all falls. The walking is through the forest with beautiful sceneries. Must take a guide for safety. ( yes, you need to pay the guide ) Please don't leave any thing behind other than your foot print. Leave the place as it is.

according to the literature this is the sri lankan highest waterfall.we went to see this in July not an attractive one due to amount of water available.may be our travelling period, this area not having get much rainfall in this period.

Excellent trip to Bambarakanda falls. You have to climb a few steps, but it reach to middle of the falls. Nice natural pond in there. However, bathing is dangerous. It is better to visit this when it is rainy, because these days no much water. Now you have to buy a ticket to entrance.
This is the highest waterfall in Sri Lanka, Must take left turn at Kalupahana Junction from Colombo - Batticaloa highway (A4). Access road is in good condition, but very narrow.

It was fantastic.  There is a climb to get to the foot of the waterfall.  Because of the steps put in place it's not difficult terrain. The climb will give you a good workout.  The climb is worth.  Smaller entrance fee is charged to pay the salaries of the people working there.  Please do not litter on the way or after you get there.  Help keep it beautiful and natural. Just sitting at the foot of the fall was also so relaxing and calming.

It's high and beautiful waterfall. It's located near the main road. The road to waterfall is narrow, but is good enough. We were riding on a motorcycle without any problems. The entrance fee is 150 rupees. There are 2 toilets on the territory. In April there was nobody except of us!
It's close to the road and so it takes only a few minutes to get a selfie. That is what most of the people do.

I was there with my friends on February 2017. Bambarakanda is highest waterfall of Sri Lanka. 790 feet high. Belihull Oya , the one who makes such magnificent view. Turn at Haldummulla , Kalupahana junction and it will take 20 mins by car. Or at the junction there are three wheelers and it costs like 500/= to the water fall. You have to buy a ticket at the entrance. After 20 mins of walk from the ticket counters you will arrive to the waterfall. But DO NOT try to climb the rocks or have a bath. It could be very dangerous. Enjoy and safe . Cheers !
far away from Haputale and not so much water but beauty enough. be aware of monkeys. pool at downstream also ok.

This is the tallest waterfall of Sri Lanka. The path to the falls is well built. We went there with our two kids. There are even toilet facilities besides the road too. The path to the falls is very much scenic. Best time to visit the falls is rainy season. Can get a cold water bath too. Take in to the mind that we must not pollute this spectacular place.

Bambarakanda Falls is off the Beragala to Haputale road. A very narrow winding road goes upward until you see the falls. At 263 metres (863 feet) this is the tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka and apparently the 299th highest in the world. The falls were spectacular in December because of regular rain experienced in the area. We didn't walk to the falls because there were probably lots of leaches.

Awesome place! There was not much water when we went there. But we could manage a proper bath at the very bottom of the waterfall. Water was so cold. It passes with the time you spend in the water. Wasn't that crowded in the morning but many people came in the afternoon. There is a seating area that you can sit and enjoy the waterfall. The same place has access to many other waterfalls like Lanka Ella.
We arrived the day after the rain and the largest waterfall in Srilanka was more than a little stream. Nice and easy walk to the top.

You can see breathtaking views while you go there. You can see the water fall from both top and bottom. It was a nice hike with pine trees around you. Make sure you take a shower from the water fall. Don't afraid. Cz everyone do it. While you go there you can cover lanka waterfall too.

It was an amazing experience to witness Sri Lanka's tallest water fall in real life after reading much about it in the past. Tickets for locals cost Rs 30. The drive to the falls is a bit tedious. Amazing views . Clean toilets located along the climb. Went in holiday season so unfortunately there were any people drunk and dancing in their underwear at the top. All in all the experience was awesome.

This is the tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka. But when considering the amount of water it has, it is not much rich. We visited this place during our stay at the Bambarakanda Holiday Resort and it was a walk of few hundreds meters. a good point to highlight here is, you can reach to the top of the waterfall without much effort and that is a unique experience to have with a nice view.

Being the tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka it doesn't seem to have a large volume of water, yet it is a sight to behold. The base of the waterfall can be reached after a 10-15 min walk uphillfrom the sitecwhere vehicles can be parked. You have to buy a ticket, one hopes that proceeds go towards maintenance of the stairs, toliet and general upkeep of this site. The path leads up through a pine forest. The water is cold!!!

It is situated in Beragala a little away from Haputale and is a 15min ride up a hill. the road is quite narrow at certain points. A ticket is required to enter the pathway to view the falls up close but the view from afar is also beautiful. A 10min walk/climb will take you close up tot he water fall. This is the highest water fall in Sri Lanka. It didn't look that great as there was not much water.

its the tallest Waterfall in SL. A must visit for every tourist if coming this way. Lodging can be done at the guest house 'Bambarakanda Rest'... Amazing Site and hikers can hike up the hill... leaches are there so be prepared.... Amazing view..

Me and my wife went to this place a few months back, and it was a place that we could actually spend hours without being bored.Being tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka, it is located in a very calm, quiet and a very nice area without being urbanized. The environment and the climate is very comforting, the air and the water in the area is so clean and it truly is a place for relaxation. You can get into the water where the water falls, but this place seemed to be less dangerous as well (but not sure, so be careful). The road to the waterfall is rough, but I saw even small cars had arrived. However, that definitely would be a worthy trip ultimately! It is not a very crowded place, so you can stay for a long without rushing! You will have to buy a ticket, but it's cheap. If you want to buy some food, please keep it purchased earlier because you wouldn't find many stalls out there. Anyway, please do not throw any empty food containers or garbage in this area; because, it's a place that everybody should try to protect for the future!!!

I was looking forward to visiting the highest waterfall after 3 years, but what they managed to do there is just ridiculous. First, foreigners have to pay the entrance fee. Just 100lkr per p. but why?? Then the concrete stairs with disgusting hut with toilets. And finally, they build something like concrete balcony on the rock in front of the waterfall and put the sign that you shouldn't go to the water. Like why?? The water is cold, but it's all completely safe, specially in March, when there is not much water. After all, in my opinion they ruined a nice place and made an average attraction, not worth visiting if you don't have something better to do.

A difficult access road, about 4 kms, for larger vehicles. Even at the time of my first visit some 4 years ago it was just a trickle due to the absence of sufficient rains. It can be reached on foot with a short walk after driving as far as possible.

This water falls is situated a few km away from main road but you can travel in a vehicle very close to the water fall. Walking distance is about 200m. This does not have very much water in dry season and this is not as beautiful as some other smaller water falls in Sri Lanka. Anyway you can bath at the base pond CAREFULLY. If you are travelling along A4 road this is a worth place to visit....

Take any bus towards Colombo from Haputale. Ask to get off at Bambarakanda falls approx. 40 minutes. Tuk-tuks will be waiting, take one one-way and go to the falls. Lovely peaceful place (bring picknick) and a nice 4km walk back downhills. Then take a bus back to Haputale. Perfekt halfday trip!

One of the highlights of my travel in Sri Lanka. It's very easy to walk to the waterfall - just following the road and last bit by a path. The entrance fee is 150 RPS and it's worthy. The waterfall is amazing and you can swim under! Very refreshing and super crazy feeling standing under 200m tall waterfall.

This is a must see if you are in the area. We spent an afternoon hiking around the falls - there are trails that go behind and around, connecting to other waterfalls. The trail is super interesting: one moment you are in an evergreen forest, the next through tall grass, and suddenly walking on a stony path that resembles an enchanted garden. Hike is medium level. Wear good shoes. We camped near the falls and could see that somebody else was camping at the top of the falls with a campfire. If you like natural beauty and hiking, this place is a must visit.
On our way back from Wellawaya - Beragala we stopped for a short while. an attractive place and relaxed.

i went this place several times. now this place became modify by the government.specially the path to reach the water fall..its a good sign even to charge a fare to enter this. because now they have to take care of the people and the vehicles come their.even for a family its a nice one day trip to have a good fun.but dont go to this place during the rainy season.because its very very dangerous...in dry season its very safe....
This is a must see landmark if you are visiting Nuwara Eliya, Haputale or Badulla area. Don't expect something like Niagara falls, but this is the tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka.

Went their with family and friends. 160 km away from Colombo and takes about 4 hours without traffic. You can reach the fall by vehicle (even a car) and a small hike through the brush, which is brilliant. Can go up to where the fall makes a small pool. Absolutely breathtaking !!!
if you like waterfall bathing, one of the best place highly recommended to visit lanka falls which is located closer to bambarakanda

The route to the falls from the main road (Haputale) is about 7km and you could see the waterfall from a distance. But it is highly recommended that you go to pool itself which is about 700m walk in from the entrance. Locals are charged Rs. 50 and foreigners $2 if I remember it right. MUST DO: Dip your head into the fall. It's amaazing!

If it is not raining , the fall is a trickle . We were lucky that it started pouring as soon as we arrived - the trickle became a raging torrent in a few minutes .  The walkway to the fall pool is pretty tough in patches - but a reasonably fit person should make it . No flip flops - only proper sports shoes please .  The entry charge is SLR 125 per person - with no receipt - probably another Sri Lankan rip off for foreigners . They are really out to make hay while the Sun shines - except in this particular  place - don't go if the Sun is shining . Tallest fall is important but their should be reasonable water too . There are clean and free [ surprise surprise ] toilets at two places and a couple of covered shelters on the way .

Bambarakanda is the highest waterfall in Sri Lanka, but not much rich in water when compare with some others in country. You have to tern from Kalupahana junction (near 172 km post) of Colombo Haputhale road and travel another 3.5km to visit the falls. There are 2 things I like on this water fall. First one is that you can access the base of the fall most of the time and get good pictures of it. Second one is that you can access the top of it (by some hiking that take around 30 mins) to get a fabulous view of the place. There are two more waterfalls nearby that you can visit by hiking.
That was the most scenic water fall of all which a saw at Sri Lanka. It need 4 WD for tip to Kalupahana Ohiya road,where is Babmarakanda.
Nice place to relax if you like the nature, rain forest, fire flies, crickets and leaches.    ........ Great fall of the H2O ...... Awesome ........... do not miss ..........
Bambarakanda Falls is the tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka. With a height of 263 m, it ranks as the 299th highest waterfall in the world. Situated in Kalupahana in the Badulla District,

Tallest water fall in Sri Lanka. Young lads can hike and go the peak of the fall. There is a small lake like in the top. Can have a bath. Can enjoy good landscapes of Haputale and Beragala from the top. Wonderful place for Photographs. Must is be Safe.
Nice walk through villages and nature with a nice waterfall at the end. It is a bit Climbing and aveage steep. Take enough water with you.

I have visited Bamabarakanda waterfall and surrounding another four waterfalls in January 2015. Bambarakanda had good flow of water due to good rainfall at Hortain plains. There is a ticket issuing counter at the entrance of the waterfall and nice foot pathway has been made to the base pool of the waterfall. Following that we climbed to top of the waterfall and then walk towards another waterfall called Lanka Falls . It is better you have a guide to visit other waterfalls including Lanka Falls, Yalathanna Falls (hidden beauty), Uduwara Falls and Nagadowa Falls. You can get more information from http://trips.lakdasun.org/roaming-in-bambarakanda-and-haldummulla.htm

First ... how to find this hidden paradise... if you have access to google map just type bambarakanda falls, within seconds you will get the directions( here im attaching a map from google) or else just remember its in between beragala and belihuloya in A4 road. From there a 5km hike to the waterfall. The road itself is a picturesque one, with wonderful scenery all around. Never forget your camera if you are a nature enthusiasts.  You will find few small villages on your way to top. Mind it its very narrow road but still you can drive a van/suv/mpv. When you reach the summit from the you have to walk around 2km to the waterfall. Newly built steps will help you to ease yourself. On the way 2 clean public toilets are available. Once you reach the bottom of the waterfall .....what can i say..... just enjoy the moment... but remember never try to swim or bath in the natural pool though its very tempting...!!!!
One of the must visit places in Sri Lanka... You will find a wonderful lady who runs her own stay... Very affordable.

Rs1400 return from Haputale (including waiting time) in a tuk tuk. Would have much more water after rains! Only a short walk from the carpark. Nice cooling plunge pool to paddle in - actual swimming is discouraged and we saw no one doing it!

Its on A 4 route from Colombo. 160 KM post you get Kalupahana Junction . From there you have to turn towards Hortain Plains by walk or by Vehicle another 5 KM. Its motor-able up to the car park. It starts from Hortain plains and go on a rocky route to Samanalawewa Reservoir, Closer to Balangoda. Big buses can not go up the water fall but any other vehicle or motor cycle is possible. If you go on peddle bicycle you will have to push it in steep hills!!!!!!!!!!!!

Bambarakanda Waterfall is the longest water fall in Sri Lanka. The journey to the bottom of the fall is through a narrow and difficult climb.It is a motorable road but at the top you have to walk a few meters to reach the water fall. The view of the fall is fantastic but recommend only for those appreciating scenic beauty. From Colombo you go through Ratnapura and take the Balangoda road. Balangoda has a beautiful Rest House where you can have a good Rice and Curry meal. From Balangoda you drive up to Haputale through Beragala. From Beragala you can see all the way to Uda Walawe and Kirinda in deep south on a clear day. The road to Bambarakanda is between Beragala and Haputale. If you want to see Bambarakanda falls I suggest you stay over at Haputale for the night. There are enough vacation rentals and a new hotel to stay in Haputale. From Haputale you can go down to Bandarawela another Holiday town. While in Haputale you should visit Adisham Bungalow a former residence of a scottish gentlemen now run by the catholic priests.The scenic drive from Balangoda to Bandarawela is worth doing when holidaying in Sri Lanka. My last visit was around August 2012. I rate the Bambarakanda Waterfall visit average because of the roadway leading to falls but the waterfall is worth seing.

We wanted to visit because these are the highest falls in sri lanka. Not spectacular but certainly pretty and worth the visit. We were initially told we would need to take a tuktuk from the main road because the road to the falls is too narrow. This was not the case, our van made it to the parking spot about 1km from the falls although it IS very narrow. If you enjoy long walks then it would be a nice walk from the main road, good scenery and a small village, about 5km all along narrow paved road with almost no traffic. There is no entrance fee and almost no tourists, we only passed a group of local uni students on their way out. And there is a couple of nice seats to sit and admire the falls for a while. Our guide also gave us a bottle of soapy water for leeches but we only encountered one.

I went there twice in 8 months already because I just love it. Within 8 months they constructed steps along the way, toilets and a platform to watch the fall from afar.. Go there fast before they set up an entrance fee and it becomes overpopulated with tourists! (++) very few tourists at the moment if writing this review (++) cool, refreshing, clean water for bath (++) still unspoilt and picture perfect (++) 20 minutes walk, not tiring Advise: drive up the main road another kilometer (maybe less) and stop by Bambarakanda Rest. It has an amazing garden/house where you can eat with a direct open view on the fall. The lady of the house makes really good rice and curry. It's heaven on earth for nature lovers!
This is unspoilt natural charm. I enjoyed the scramble over the rocks. Worth a look if you are passing.

Sri Lanka's highest waterfall. Have to walk about 6 km from the main road to the location. I'd say walk that coz its a nice trekking path with some beautiful scenery. The fall itself is a magnificent view. The water spray from the waterfall is awesome a feeling.

Very beautiful falls, nice location. Away from the hustle and bustle of the city, the only sounds will be of water and chirps of birds. Only about one Km of trekking is required to reach the falls from the parking spot (the trek from the main road is about 5-6 Km). The best experience is when bathing at foot of the falls and looking up to see the water flowing from high above. What a sight ! And the water is very Cool.

After passing Beluhuloya on A4 road close to Kalupahana you will come across weli oya bridge . Just passing weli oya bridge you get a narrow road on to your left. At the starting point of that gap you will see small shops and a small bo-tree with a buddha statue. The road is a  narrow one but tarred and  quite ok. You have to travel about 3km on this road and there is a place to park the vehicles . To reach the bottom of the fall you have to walk on a small track through pine forest. At the bottom of the fall , there's  a lovely pool and you must take a bath . The water is very cold and it will refresh you the moment you get in to water. When we went there,  there were no rains and it is dry season and there were very little water. Village folks said November - February they get a lot of rains and after that the fall starts to have the full flow. We saw a lot of construction work is carrying out and it will ease the visitors to reach the water fall but it is taking off the natural beauty of the surrounding. visited September 2013
Sri Lanka's highest and most attractive weaterfall.  Hard to find and takes a long walk but the effort was worth it.
It was really beautiful falls, I highly recommended for photographers especially for those who like to capture the motion of water.
When we visited there hadn't been a lot of rain, so they were not their their best, but still very picturesque.

The highest waterfall in Sri Lanka has an easy access, in our case 30 mins by tuktuk from Haputale.There's no entrance fee and no tourists. Behind a small bridge you may go to the right to reach the bottom of the fall behind a huge stone or go to the left and follow a hardly visible path to reach the bottom in about 45 mins. Both ways will be difficult for not prepared people. At least the good shoes are needed. There are pools where you may refresh yourself after a hard walk.

nice fall in between beautiful hills. lovely small walk in the beautiful plain to reach the highest water fall in Lanka. really a great place to swim and best to visit during september-december as the water would be more

Bambarakanda is the tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka; situated in Kalupahana in Badulla district. There are two ways to reach Bambarakanda; both are full of unbelievable sceneries: Colombo-->Ratnapura-->Balangoda-->Kalupahana Badulla-->Bandarawella-->Haputale-->Beragala-->Kalupahana We stayed at Sera Mayakaduwaâ€™s lodge; who is well-known as the lonely lady who takes the care of Bambarakanda fall. The rock which is next to the waterfall looks like a couple hugging each others (knows as the Bambarakanda Lovers). Best view of this can be seen at the Seraâ€™s lodge. Before the Bambarakanda we went to the Lanka Ella which is another amazing waterfall, situated very close to Bambarakanda. There are 2 ways to reach Lanka Ella. Harder one is with rock climbing which needs bit of experience in hiking. Easy one through a lovely Pine forest. On our way, we went to the Bambarakanda base and had a nice shower from the base pool. Its a priceless experience. No words to explain the beauty of the sceneries.
place is very green, but no good road while going there.

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Sri-Lankan-water-falls/132599536802665 Guess all know how to reach to this falls. But I would like to add something more. Apart from the main water fall there are two other falls on top of the main fall, you should climb through the mountain and will find this small stunning waterfalls.for sure you can get directions from the villages. there is another one near this falls called 'Lanka Ella', which you should walk further to the jungle side.

A small hike and you arrive at the tallest waterfall in Srilanka. You can actually walk right up to the base of the waterfall and take a shower from the tallest shower in Srilanka. Most of the times, the top of the falls is covered in mist and the falls truly becomes a shower from heaven.

Bambarakanda waterfall is the highest waterfall in Sri Lanka. i visited this place last year you can get a great view once you go near to the waterfall ,also if you go prepared you can have a cool bath in the base pool.
